Meta.title: Corporate training
Meta.description: Promotional element, used on every training page

Meta.title: Example block
Meta.body:
This is a description of what it is and how it should be used.

Lorem ipsum dictum cras consectetuer. Rutrum mi vestibulum diam senectus ridiculus platea lacinia tortor sed. Tellus eu ligula duis quis elit placerat. Iaculis sed ac. Magna adipiscing est non. In eu vel per quisque nec posuere id torquent. Elit facilisis erat potenti id. Fusce sed velit sed proin. In velit velit pharetra.

HTML

    

<div id="privateheader">
	<h2>Corporate training</h2>
</div>       		
<div id="privatecourses">
<h3>Digital skills development</h3>
<p>We work within your organisation to guide your team's skill development, providing benefits above and beyond our regular training services</p>
<p class="more"><a href="/training/corporate-training.shtml">about corporate training</a></p>
</div>

How it looks like

CSS used in the module

        	

#privateheader h2 {
	font:3.1em gil,"trebuchet MS",helvetica,sans-serif;
	line-height:.9em;
	background: url(../i-2012/private.gif) no-repeat 0 0;
	min-height:95px;
	padding-left:115px;
	padding-bottom:25px;
	text-transform: lowercase;
	padding-top:20px;
	margin-bottom:0;
	margin-top:0
}
#privatecourses {
	padding-bottom:5px;
	background: url(../i-2012/stars-high.gif) no-repeat 50% 100%;
	margin-bottom:10px
}

Meta.title: Responsive grid
Meta.body:
The responsive grid is key in the creation of a responsive website. We use 8 columns in large screens, and 4 columns in small devices, with a gutter of 10px. This can be configured in the _config.scss file.

The site has only one breakpoint at 55em (550px).

Classes largeN will be active at screens bigger than 550px, and the smallN below that figure, allowing you to have different layouts for the same page, on large and small devices.

Example of grid for a large device only

	
<div class="row">
  <div class="large8 col">8</div>
</div>
<div class="row">
  <div class="large1 col">1</div>
  <div class="large7 col">7</div>
</div>
<div class="row">
  <div class="large2 col">2</div>
  <div class="large5 col">5</div>
  <div class="large1 col">1</div>
</div>

How it looks like

8

1

7

2

5

1

Note: Additional code added to help visualise the grid.

Example of variable grid for small and large devices

Resize your browser to see how the layouts changes.

	
<div class="row">
  <div class="small4 large8 col">8</div>
</div>
<div class="row">
  <div class="small1 large1 col">1</div>
  <div class="small3 large7 col">7</div>
</div>
<div class="row">
  <div class="small4 large4 col">4</div>
  <div class="small4 large4 col">4</div>
</div>

How it looks like

8 (4 in small devices)

1

7 (3 in small devices)

4

4

Note: Additional code added to help visualise the grid.

Meta.title: Form elements
Meta.body:
Every element must be part of a fieldset, otherwise the styles won't be rendered appropriately (accessiblity considerations aside).

	
<form>
  <fieldset>
    <p>
      <label>This is the label</label>
      <input type="text" value="Some predefined text here">
    </p>
  </fieldset>
</form>

Buttons

Normal button

			
<input class="button" value="Normal Button">

Primary action button

			
<input class="button primary" value="Primary action">

Disabled button

			
<input class="button disabled" disabled value="Disabled">

Submit button

			
<input type="submit" value="Submit button">

Fields

A standard text input field, with label

This is help text under the form field.

			
<label>Normal text input field</label>
<input type="text" placeholder="Some predefined text here">
<p class="form-help">This is help text under the form field.</p>

An input field meant for URLs, with label

			
<label for="url">URL</label>
<input type="url" id="url" class="form-text" placeholder="http://yourdomain.com" />

Some radio buttons, with label

			
<label>Normal text input field</label>
<input type="text" value="Some predefined text here">

A textarea, with label

			
<fieldset>
  <label for="bio">Bio</label>
  <textarea id="bio"></textarea>
</fieldset>

The classic T&Cs checkbox that nobody reads

			
<fieldset class="check">
  <label><input type="checkbox" /> I accept the terms of service and lorem ipsum.</label>
</fieldset>

Form errors

Add how your form displays errors here.

Search form

Add how the search form looks like, if different than a normal input field.

Meta.title: Article
Meta.body:
Document how this template works here.

Header

Breadcrumb

Local nav

Most read

Article content

Comments

Related articles

Footer

  • Header
  • Breadcrumb. Should display the name of the article as the last child, selected and not linked
  • Local navigation. Links to the different sub-categories, with the current one selected.
  • Most read. List of the most read articles of the last 48 hours
  • Article
  • Comments. If enabled in the CMS, visitors can read and add comments
  • Related articles
  • Footer

Meta.title: Breadcrumb
Meta.body:
With the exception of the homepage, the breadcrumb block should be on every page to help visitors navigate the page, and understand the content's hierarchy.

How it looks like

  • Home
  • Category
  • Current page

HTML

   	

<nav class="breadcrumb">
  <ul>
    <li><a href="#">Home</a></li>
    <li><a href="#">Category</a></li>
    <li><strong>Current page</strong></li>
  </ul>
</nav>

SCSS

	

/*BREADCRUMB*/
nav.breadcrumb {
	font-size: 1.4rem;
	color: #3A8EE2;
	margin-bottom: 2em;

	ul li {
		float: left;
		list-style: none;
	}

	a {
		margin: 0 5px;
		text-decoration: none;
	}
	a:first-child {
		margin-left: 0;
	}

	a:hover, a:focus {
		color: $primary-color;
	}

	strong {
		font-weight: bold;
		color: $primary-color;
	}		

}
